Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3SP2-93V0-006F-X3VR-00000-00US envoy arrives, calls for negotiated solution1997-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-08-04T18:52:36ZLexisNexisPart 5 Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean; AFRICA; CENTRAL AFRICA; ZAIRE; AL/D2906/AUS envoy arrives, calls for negotiated solution

[1]

Text of report by Zairean radio on 28th April

The United States is convinced that no military solution is possible. This statement was made today by Ambassador Bill Richardson, the US president's emissary.

Source: Voix du Zaire, Kinshasa, in French 1800 gmt 28 Apr 97

This diplomat, who has the rank of a cabinet minister at the State Department, was welcomed at Ndjili airport by Henri Thomas Lopo Beonka [phonetic], deputy minister of foreign affairs and international cooperation. Also present at the ceremony was US Ambassador Daniel Simpson.

Ambassador Richardson said that after his talks on 29th April with President Mobutu, he would meet the leader of the armed movement, Laurent-Desire Kabila, on 30th April.

In a message read at the Intercontinental Hotel hall, President Bill Clinton's emissary called for a negotiated solution that will lead to the formation of a transitional government that will not exclude anyone, as well as the holding of fair and free elections. He said that he would work towards achieving a peaceful, prosperous and democratic future in Zaire. Answering a correspondent's question, Ambassador Richardson said that he will consolidate his efforts in order to present President Bill Clinton with a clear idea about the current situation. My objective, he said, is to initiate talks for peace and negotiations, and to improve the human rights situation.
